Control can be by using resistant varieties, such as Srikandi, Lamuru, and Gumarang. In addition, planting can be done simultaneously and carry out a period of time free from corn plants at least two weeks to one month each year. If there are already infected, eradication or total destruction can be carried out. For prevention, metalaxyl fungicides can also be used on plant seeds with a dose of 0.7 grams of active ingredient per kg of seed

Control can be by using resistant varieties, such as Bima 1, Sukmaraga, and Palakka. If infected plants are seen, they must be eradicated immediately. Can also be given a fungicide with the active ingredients mancozeb and carbendazim.

Symptoms of this disease occur on the surface of the corn leaves which are white to yellowish followed by chlorotic stripes and another characteristic is that in the morning on the underside of the corn leaves there is a layer of white velvet. Downy mildew in maize causes systemic symptoms that extend to all parts of the plant and cause local symptoms. Plants infected with downy mildew at a young age usually do not form fruit, but if the infection occurs in older plants, fruit is still formed and generally stunted growth.

Symptoms of this disease occur when leaf spots appear yellowish green or reddish brown. When affected corn seedlings may wilt or die within 3–4 weeks. If the infected cobs will cause the seeds to be damaged and rotten, the cobs can even fall. Infection with this disease can be carried by wind or rain splashes and can cause the first infection of corn plants.
